Title: üé¨üñº A cargo ship with 20 thousand tons of saltpeter from Russia ...
Description: A cargo ship with 20 thousand tons of saltpeter from Russia has not been able to get up for repairs in Europe for more than a month. Local authorities fear a repeat of the tragedy in Beirut The Malta-flagged cargo ship MV Ruby carrying Russian fertilizers has not been allowed into European ports for repairs since the beginning of September. European authorities are afraid of the possible detonation of 20 thousand tons of ammonium nitrate (ammonium nitrate), which Ruby was supposed to deliver to Africa from the Murmansk region. The New York Times writes about this.Ruby left the port in the city of Kandalaksha in August. Soon after the start of the journey, the ship ran aground, resulting in damage to the hull, propeller and rudder. From September 1 to September 4, the ship was in the Norwegian port of Tromso - there it was inspected, but not repaired. Since then, the ship has not been allowed to dock.Ammonium nitrate is a popular fertilizer that comes with risks. Nitrate is explosive, especially in large quantities. Heating or, for example, a significant change in air humidity can lead to an explosion. In August 2020, due to welding work in the port of Lebanese Beirut, 2,750 tons of saltpeter detonated - as a result of a powerful explosion (on video), more than 200 people were killed, and about 300,000 more were left homeless. There is about 8 times more saltpeter on board Ruby - although it is known that the ship was not damaged by the cargo. The opportunity to moor the ship with explosive cargo MV Ruby has already been denied by the authorities of Lithuania and Great Britain, off whose coast the ship has been docking for the last week. Now the UAE company that operates the vessel, Serenity Shipping, has requested permission to dock to unload fertilizer onto another vessel and carry out repairs on the Ruby. Even Malta refused to allow Ruby with explosive cargo, writes The New York Times. This is despite the fact that the ship is flying the Maltese flag. Officials said the Ruby would only be able to dock if it got rid of the saltpeter.
